tr.td: Title:Active Star Formation in Infrared Dark Clouds
Co-I(s): James Jackson, Jill Rathborne, Ed Chambers, Ronak Shah, Robert Simon

body.div: \Abstract{ Infrared Dark Clouds (IRDCs), a new class of molecular cloud identified as deep mid-IR extinction features, are probably the precursors to stellar clusters. Recent 1.2 mm continuum survey of IRDCs reveals that they contain many compact cores with typical masses of 100\,\Msun\, and sizes $\leq$ 0.5 pc. \Spitzer\, 3--8\,\um\, and 24\,\um\, images reveal $\sim$ 1/3 of these cores are sites of active star formation. The bright unresolved 24\,\um\, continuum sources detected by \Spitzer\, directly indicate embedded protostars. In addition, the active cores contain extended 3--8\,\um\ emission, with an enhancement at 4.5\,\um\ that might arise from shocked H$_{2}$. Molecular line emission towards the cores show broad linewidths of HCN (4--3) and CS (3--2) and strong SiO (2--1) emission, also indicative of star formation. The active cores' large mm/submm/IR bolometric luminosities of $>$10,000\,\Lsun\, indicate that either a single high-mass protostar or a number of lower-mass protostars are present within each core. We therefore request Gemini-N/Michelle time to determine the small-scale structure of the bright 24\,\um\, sources in order to distinguish between single and multiple protostars and Gemini-N/NIRI time to investigate the enhanced 4.5\,\um\, emission of these cores. }
